awd_titl_txt: Enhancing the Success of Women in Vision Science: Females of Vision, et al. (FoVea)
awd_abstract_narration: The goal of Women in Cognitive Science is to improve the visibility of women scientists by fostering an environment that welcomes and nurtures young women scholars, to contribute to the professional development of scholars throughout their career, and to facilitate creation of a network that will provide contacts and connections to other women in science. Several workshops are designed for women in cognitive science, especially women in the early stages of their academic career. The workshops focus on negotiation techniques to create opportunities and optimize mechanisms to sustain research visibility and productivity. A second focus is on grant application writing for predoctoral, postdoctoral, and early career scientists. Workshops will take place at meetings of the Psychonomic Society, the Cognitive Science Society, and the Association for Psychological Sciences. The workshops will take the form of a public forum with invited speaker-panelists to initiate discussion about best practices for the professional advancement of women in cognitive science at the individual and institutional level. By partnering with these established societies, the workshops will maximize the outreach potential to a group that continues to be underrepresented in senior academic positions in the cognitive sciences.

por.por_cntn:
NSF 1645442 Outcomes

The goal of the activities supported by this grant was to enhance the success of women vision scientists. Toward this aim, the PIs formed a group, "Females of Vision, et al." (FoVea), at the Vision Sciences Society (VSS) Meeting in May 2015. A fourth member joined the FoVea organizing committee later that year. We received support in the form of a conference grant from the NSF for our efforts at, or in conjunction with, the Vision Sciences Society Meeting. The "et al." in FoVea's name signals that, although the focus is on promoting and advising women scientists, who are so often left behind in the current climate, FoVea cooperates with people of all genders with the goal of creating a diverse and equitable vision science community. In the years since we received this award, our advocacy has had a visible impact on the gender representation of speakers, awardees, and committee members of the Vision Sciences Society (VSS); on the availability of networking opportunities and career advice for women vision scientists; and on the visibility of women in vision science.

Gender Representation: Due in large part to our efforts, there has been an increase in the percentage of women (1) nominated for awards (one can?t win unless one is nominated); (2) named as the VSS Young Investigator: from 12% (2007-2015 before we began our advocacy) to 57% since (2016-2022); (2) giving platform talks (38% to 45%); (3) serving on the abstract review committee (16% to  44%); and (4) serving as Governing Board members (35% to 66%).

Networking Opportunities and Career Advice: Each year, FoVea invites women scientists to apply for a Travel and Networking Award to cover the cost of attending the VSS meeting. The women who have won these awards speak highly of how the award boosted their confidence and their careers. Women who applied but didn?t receive an award report that the act of applying for the award aided them in planning their careers and enhanced their experience at the conference because,  even though they did not win the monetary portion of the award, they met with and benefitted from interacting with their networking targets.

At every VSS meeting FoVea sponsors a workshop for attendees. Workshops cover topics of interest to the attendees including 1) Negotiation: When To Do It and How To Do It Successfully?; 2) Navigating a Life in Science as a Woman?, 3) Mentoring Envisioned.? These workshops provide career advice, networking opportunities, and help to establish a community of women and members of other underrepresented groups in vision. A diverse group attended the most recent workshop, including those who identified as low SES, first generation students, persons with disability, BIPOC and LGBTQIA2S+. The percentages of attendees in these groups was 33 to 44%, showing that we are reaching a broad demographic. FoVea workshops are rated highly in post-workshop surveys.

Enhancing the Visibility of Women in Vision Science. FoVea also creates, maintains, and promotes a FoVea Speaker List that is intended to increase the number of women invited to give talks at conferences and other academic events and more generally to increase the visibility of female vision scientists. We especially encourage women of all underrepresented groups to add their names to the list. Currently the FoVea Speakers List represents 287 women vision scientists. The list is accessed by, among others, those putting together symposia and colloquia. Since its inception in late 2019, the list has been accessed over 6,8000 times.

Modified by: Mary A Peterson
